com.pump.image.gif.block

Class GifGraphicControlExtension

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.image.gif.block.GifBlock
      • com.pump.image.gif.block.GifExtensionBlock
        • com.pump.image.gif.block.GifGraphicControlExtension
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GifConstants

    public class GifGraphicControlExtension
extends GifExtensionBlock
    This optional block may precede any com.bric.image.gif.block.GifGraphicRenderingBlock.

    The four static disposal modes are described below. The GIF file format describes these, but the following webpage describes them much more thoroughly:
    http://www.webreference.com/content/studio/disposal.html

    This is what the GIF file format says:

    "The Graphic Control Extension contains parameters used when processing a graphic rendering block. The scope of this extension is the first graphic rendering block to follow.

    This block is OPTIONAL; at most one Graphic Control Extension may precede a graphic rendering block. This is the only limit to the number of Graphic Control Extensions that may be contained in a Data Stream."

        protected GifGraphicControlExtension(byte[] b)

      • GifGraphicControlExtension

        public GifGraphicControlExtension(int delayTime,
                                  GifGraphicControlExtension.DisposalMethod disposalMethod,
                                  int transparentIndex)
        Creates a GifGraphicControlExtension
        Parameters:
        delayTime - the time, in hundredths of a second, this graphic shows
        disposalMethod - the disposal method.
        transparentIndex - the transparent index of the upcoming graphic. A value of -1 indicates that there is no transparent index.
        See Also:
        setDisposalMethod(DisposalMethod)

    • Method Detail

      • getDelayTime

        public int getDelayTime()
        Returns:
        the time, in hundredths of a second, that this graphic should be visible.

        The concept of a zero-length frame is not really addressed in the GIF documentation; in rare cases like this, most renderers make a point to render every frame, even if it takes more time than this value allows.

        I've noticed its often the convention of GIF decoders to force GIF frames to display for a small fixed interval, greater than 1/100 of a second, regardless of this value.

      • setDelayTime

        public void setDelayTime(int i)
        Assigns the time, in hundredths of a second, that this graphic should be visible.
        Parameters:
        i - the new delay of this frame. This must be between 0 and 65535.

      • getDisposalMethod

        public GifGraphicControlExtension.DisposalMethod getDisposalMethod()
        Returns:
        one of the four DISPOSAL_MODE values in this field. This determines what should happen after a graphic has been rendered.

      • setDisposalMethod

        public void setDisposalMethod(GifGraphicControlExtension.DisposalMethod m)
        Sets the disposal method of this graphic.
        Parameters:
        m - the new disposal method for this graphic.

      • isWaitingForUserInput

        public boolean isWaitingForUserInput()
        Returns:
        true if this graphic should not proceed to the next graphic without waiting for user input.

        This is a great idea, but I have never seen this feature supported. Ever. So I wouldn't worry about this too much.

        The GIF file format specification explains this as follows:

        "Indicates whether or not user input is expected before continuing. If the flag is set, processing will continue when user input is entered. The nature of the User input is determined by the application (Carriage Return, Mouse Button Click, etc.).

        When a Delay Time is used and the User Input Flag is set, processing will continue when user input is received or when the delay time expires, whichever occurs first."

      • setWaitingForUserInput

        public void setWaitingForUserInput(boolean b)
        Indicates whether this graphic should possibly wait for user input (if user input comes before the specified delay time). See comments in isWaitingForUserInput().
        Parameters:
        b - whether this flag is true or not.

      • getTransparentColorIndex

        public int getTransparentColorIndex()
        Returns:
        the index in the active color table that should be treated as transparent. More specifically: when this index is encountered, a pixel should be skipped, and the next pixel should should rendered.

        This may return -1 if no transparent color index is provided.

      • setTransparentColorIndex

        public void setTransparentColorIndex(int i)
        If i is non-negative, this assigns the transparent color index of this graphic to i.

        If i is negative, this "turns off" the transparent color index.

        Parameters:
        i - a value between -1 and 255. A value of -1 means there will be no transparent color index in the upcoming graphic.

      • getBytes

        public byte[] getBytes()
        Description copied from class: GifBlock
        This outputs the exact byte representation of this block.

        A series of these byte arrays combined can create a GIF file.

        Specified by:
        getBytes in class GifBlock
